Hello,

I am not sure what exactly quantitative and qualitative research me=
ans for AI (while in Psychology it is easier to define). In the following, =
I regard quantitative research as a discipline in which existing concepts a=
nd methods are used as scientific tools which makes results produced under =
the same concepts and methods quantitatively comparable to each other. On t=
he contrary, qualitative research refers to finding new concepts and method=
s that set a new starting point / new perspective for further research (a b=
it like objective search vs. novelty search).

I agree with all of you that=
 qualitative research is equally important as quantitative research. But I =
am not sure whether reviewers with a strong focus on quantitative results (=
like in Jeff's case) are the only problem.

Generally speaking, I think tha=
t most lectures just teach us some well accepted concepts and methods in wh=
ich research has been made and then remain within these boundaries and revi=
ew the current state of research. This is good for learning the technical s=
kills to make quantitative research. But you don't become sensitive for the=
 concepts themselves.

I think most researchers simply don't learn the nece=
ssary technical skills for qualitative research in AI. It is a much tougher=
 task to identify the concepts / implicit assumptions behind a proposed alg=
orithm, to determine which concept from biology has been adopted than just =
calculating some numbers and p-values. Moreover, it is even harder to find =
the right focus for your own paper and to explain in a clear and precise ma=
nner the new perspective that a proposed algorithm provides. We simply rece=
ive no training in depicting and delineating different perspectives on the =
same issue from each other using human language. 

I think this is the reas=
on why people sometimes like to write about their cool looking results rath=
er than explaining more generally how the algorithm differs from existing a=
pproaches. On the contrary, I think that neuroscientists and related resear=
chers should ask them self much more whether the existing categories we hav=
e are already appropriate to study and understand natural neural networks (=
and ultimately the human brain). 

My opinion is therefore: qualitative res=
earch needs more acceptance in the reviewing process BUT researchers also n=
eed to learn more about the technical skills that are required to perform q=
ualitative research and to explain the results to others. 

Best,
Martin
